awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Human-Pinniped Relationships & Marine Historical Ecology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to better understand the forces guiding long-term histories of human-marine animal interactions and the extent to which marine populations were resilient to human hunting pressure prior to industrialization. Taking a historical ecological approach to investigate the complex, intertwined cultural and ecological histories of the Japanese sea lion (Zalophus japonicus) throughout the late Holocene up to the extinction of this species in the mid-20th century, this study will explore the resilience of a now-extinct marine mammal species to climate change, human harvesting, and habitat disruption, as well as the reciprocal implications of this, i.e. how humans were impacted by these variations in marine productivity and prey populations. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, the project would enhance public understanding of science and the scientific method broadly disseminating its findings. Results of this research will be shared in both public and academic venues and help promote the importance of ongoing marine mammal conservation efforts.

This research uses archaeological, genetic, and isotopic data to examine how maritime hunter-gatherers and marine mammals were entangled in complex ecological relationships preceding the extinction of the Japanese sea lion. Ancient DNA from 120 samples over 12 archaeological sites is being sequenced to track changing sea lion populations through the late Holocene. The PIs are also conducting stable isotope analysis on the same sea lion samples to gain insight into changing marine ecosystems as they may have affected sea lions and people. The study improves the understanding of the human role in ecological change, and vice versa, providing comparative data for studies of human-marine ecology and maritime archaeology and history.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to better understand the millennia long dynamic relationships between humans and their marine environment. Specifically, to understand how humans and Japanese sea lion histories were intertwined in the Japanese and Kuril archipelagoes, ultimately leading to the extinction of the sea lions in the 20th century.

 

In collaboration with Japanese colleagues, we sampled over 60 Japanese sea lions from sites across Hokkaido and the Kuril Islands. We extracted mitogenomes and collagen from the samples, sequencing the DNA and performing stable isotope analysis. Mitogenome analysis allows us to investigate questions such as the population diversity of the sea lions through time, as well as population size. In combination with historical records, we are developing a fuller picture of their extinction trajectory and life history. Stable isotope analysis allows us to better understand the evolving role of the sea lions and their trophic ecology by revealing changing diets. The extinction of the Japanese Sea lion less than a century ago should have significantly altered the marine food web. Understanding the changing role Japanese sea lions played in the ecosystem prior to its extinction while subjected to varying climates, direct (hunting) and indirect (intensified fishing) anthropogenic pressures will help us better understand the implications of its extinction. In addition to understanding human impacts on the sea lions, we are also using the results of this research to better understand the extent to which hunter-gatherer populations were sensitive to marine ecological dynamics and implemented strategies to mitigate their impacts, such as targeting only male sea lions.

 

This research fills a geographical gap in the study of human interactions with marine mammals. The majority of research about human interaction with pinniped populations thus far has focused on the west coast of North America, leaving a wide knowledge gap in an important region for pinniped conservation and a historically important area for pinniped exploitation during the fur trade.

 

This research expanded networks between researchers at Hokkaido University, the University of Washington, and the Smithsonian Institution. The project has supported the training of the student co-PI and education of undergraduate students who contributed to the lab analyses. NSF funding supported the sampling of archaeological Japanese sea lion remains, processing the paleogenomic and isotopic analyses, and bioinformatics data processing. The results have been presented at several international conferences and are currently being written-up for a PhD dissertation and publication. 

 


Last Modified: 10/01/2024
Modified by: Hope Loiselle
